Name: Statue of the Sacred Apis Bull
Description: The sacred Apis bull was the personification of the Memphite god Ptah of creation and fine arts. At Saqqara, there was a cemetery for the Apis bulls known as the Serapeum, where the sacred bulls were buried in huge sarcophagi after being embalmed. During the Ptolemaic period, the cemetery of the Apis bulls was moved to Alexandria.This statue of the Apis bull is one of the best statues of this form ever found in Egypt. The bull's head is crowned by the sun disk and the uraeus (cobra). The body is ornamented with incised depictions of a necklace, a winged figure on the forelegs, and another winged figure on the hind legs. The figure is well modeled and rendered exactly in proportion. The sacred animal stands on a bronze base and a wooden sled.
